nodes.text: IoT-enabled systems can provide effective home automation that makes human life easier by enabling remote control, monitoring, and integration with other sectors
The Internet of Things (IoT) is an environment where appliances connect to sensors and the Internet to perform automated tasks and be controlled remotely
IoT enables remote control and device-to-device communication for domestic appliances, reducing need for direct user intervention
Better monitoring: IoT device-to-device transmission supports continuous monitoring of appliances and processes without user intervention
Efficiency and time savings: IoT automation avoids repetitive tasks and increases operational efficiency
Cost and energy savings: IoT enables optimum use of energy and resources through monitoring and control
Improved quality of life and smart environment: IoT and preset programs can regulate home conditions (temperature, humidity, shades) and improve comfort and convenience
Health monitoring: IoT devices can monitor health parameters and assist clinicians, seniors, and disabled people
IoT applications extend beyond homes to sectors including smart cities, industrial automation, health monitoring, and environmental monitoring

Examples of sector applications include traffic management and accident response in smart cities, vibration monitoring of infrastructure, industrial supply chain monitoring, and water pollution detection
IoT systems rely on varied communication technologies and protocols chosen for tradeoffs among range, power consumption, data rate, and cost
Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) offers short-range connectivity with significantly reduced power consumption, suitable for wearables and many IoT use cases
ZigBee provides low-power, secure, robust wireless networking suited to complex IoT sensor and control systems and has been unified in ZigBee 3.0
A major limitation of IoT adoption is privacy and security risks plus a usability gap for non-expert users, which can hinder trust and equitable access
WiFi provides high data rates and wide existing infrastructure in homes but can be too power-consuming for many IoT applications
LoRaWAN targets low-power wide-area IoT with support for large networks and low data rates, suitable for smart city and industrial sensor deployments
